s.text: According to the inspector, the state's concern wasn't the condemned: The guards were worried that if the chair broke apart during an electrocution, the thick, black, high-voltage wires screwed to the inmate might rip loose and electrocute everybody in the room.

The flames are nearly a foot high, they arc out from underneath the black leather hood; there is smoke, the huge buzzing sound of the electricity, there are white walls and Venetian blinds and linoleum underfoot.
If tidy executions were the point, Florida could have switched over to lethal injection a long time ago.
Down there, more than in other places, electricity is power, the fine bright line between life and no life, which is the same thing as between life and death.
The electric chair came to the state in the middle of the first great Florida land boom, when Florida was conjuring itself up out of the sea of grass.
The electric chair came to the state in the middle of the first great Florida land boom, when Florida was conjuring itself up out of the sea of grass.

The problem was that hangings were popular and sometimes drew huge, raucous, picnicking crowds, an image that didn't quite mesh with the orange-blossom gentility the land barons were trying to create.
The electric chair came to the state in the middle of the first great Florida land boom, when Florida was conjuring itself up out of the sea of grass.

At six minutes past 7, the electricity hits Jesse Tafero and his head bursts into flame.
Davis started to bleed when the electricity hit him, soaking his shirt bright red, scaring the assembled witnesses.
The guards slip a black leather hood over his face and screw the head electrode, with its circular sponge, down onto the top of his skull.
In 1924, the Florida legislature moved death indoors to the chair, away from the curious and the mayonnaise-smeared.
